summary: This is an email chain from October 2019 discussing the referral of victims of Jeffrey Epstein to counseling services. The correspondence reveals confusion and concern over appropriate, trauma-focused service providers for victims, highlighting the sensitive nature of the case and the impact of Epstein's suicide and media attention on a victim in West Palm Beach.

events.title: Victim requests counseling
events.description: An Epstein victim in West Palm Beach contacts authorities via text, stating that Epstein's suicide and constant media attention at her house have severely affected her, creating an urgent need for counseling services.

events.title: Referral list shared
events.description: A list of three agencies (Catholic Charities, Palm Beach County Victim Services, International Rescue Committee) is shared as potential referrals for Epstein victims.

events.title: Concerns raised about referrals
events.description: An email expresses confusion and concern that the provided referral list contains a non-working number and an immigration-focused agency, which is inappropriate for a sex trafficking case. It notes that executive management requires trauma-focused, vetted agencies for these sensitive victim referrals.

keyFacts: An Epstein victim in West Palm Beach was severely distressed by Epstein's suicide and by reporters constantly going to her house, leading her to seek counseling services in August 2019.

Authorities were compiling a referral list for victim services but expressed concern in October 2019 that some referrals were inappropriate (e.g., an immigration agency) or non-functional for a sex trafficking case.
Executive management had instructed that due to the case's sensitivity, victims must be referred only to trauma-focused and vetted agencies.
The email chain highlights operational challenges and the need for specialized care in supporting the victims of the Epstein case.
